_exec_summary.SummaryText:
As used throughout this Risk Management Plan (RMP), the term "Facility" means the 283-W Water Treatment Facility (283-W Facility) and not the approximately 586 square mile U.S. Department of Energy Hanford Site.  The standard industrial source code for the Hanford Site is 9999.  There is no corresponding North American Industry Classification System (NAICS) number.  The NAICS number for the 283-W Facility is 22131, Water Supply and Irrigation Systems.



The 283-W Facility is located on the U.S. Department of Energy Hanford Site.  The 283-W Facility receives raw water from the Columbia River, treats (filters and disinfects) the raw water, and exports the treated water for process, fire protection, potable, and irrigation purposes in accordance with Washington Administrative Code, Chapter 246-290, Drinking Water Regulations.  One step of the treatment process is chlorination.  In the chlorination system, the 283-W Facility uses gaseous chlorine, stored at the facility in 1-ton chlorine containers, for injection into the raw, untreated facility influent and for disinfection of post-filtration effluent.  Chlorine is used as an algaecide and disinfectant.  Evaluation of the 283-W Facility and chlorine storage capacity indicates that the 283-W Facility stores or has the potential to store a chlorine inventory in excess of the threshold quantity (2,500 lb); therefore, the 283-W Facility is subject to Risk Management (RM) Program regulations.  



The 283-W Facility is subject to additional regulations related to the management of chemicals.  The 283-W Facility is subject to the reporting requirements under the Emergency Planning and Community Right to Know Act of 1986 and the Occupational Safety and Health Administration Process Safety Management Rule, which also contains provisions for the safe management of chemicals.  Because the chlorine containers periodically are transported to the facility, the chlorine is stored in containers that are compliant with the U.S. Depar

tment of Transportation regulations.  These regulations require periodic retesting of the containers to ensure container integrity. 



Each of the prime contractors for the U.S. Department of Energy Richland Operations Office have developed a similar approach to the management of chemicals that is consistent with the principles of integrated safety management.  The Hanford Chemical Management Program is used to evaluate the adequacy of individual project/facility chemical management programs, identify opportunities for improvement in the safe and efficient management of chemicals, implement changes to existing chemical management programs, develop chemical management systems, as appropriate, and control day-to-day management of chemicals on the Hanford Site. 



Processes subject to the RM Program requirements are divided into three eligibility levels, referred to as Programs 1, 2, and 3.  Program 1 is available to any process that has not had an accidental release with offsite consequences in the past 5 years and has no public receptors within the distance to the toxic endpoint associated with a worst-case scenario (WCS).  Processes subject to Program 1 must conduct and document a WCS, must coordinate emergency response activities with local responders, and must certify compliance as part of the RMP submission.  



Based on this information, the 283-W Facility is a Program 1 process. 



Processes subject to Program 1:



 Need not identify one WCS for all toxics and one alternative scenario for each toxic chemical/substance



 Need not identify one WCS and one alternative scenario for each flammable chemical 



 Need not conduct a refined modeling analysis



 Need not develop an accident prevention program.

 

Toxic endpoints have been established in the RM Program guidance for chlorine.  The toxic endpoint for chlorine is 0.0087 milligrams per liter.  



The WCS assumed a complete release from one cylinder (2,000 lbs.) of chlorine.  Using the U.S. Environm

ental Protection Agency-developed "look-up" tables (EPA 550 B 99 009), WCS distance to the toxic endpoint is 3 miles and the area affected by the release is 28 square miles.  The effected population was estimated at 914 people located within the effected area.  Because this area of the Hanford Site is not accessible to the public, no public receptors are within the WCS release area.  As a Program 1 process, no alternative release scenario was conducted as part of this RM Program.  However, alternative release scenarios were conducted during facility hazard assessments and analyses.



According to the Hanford Site Environmental Report for Calendar Year 2002, Appendix G (PNNL 14295), there are no plants or mammals on the federal list of endangered and threatened wildlife and plants within the WCS release area.  However, one bird (bald eagle) and two fish (spring run chinook salmon and steelhead) species are on the list of threatened and endangered species.  Furthermore, two species of plants (Umtanum desert buckwheat and White Bluffs bladderpod), one species of mammal (Washington ground squirrel), and one species of bird (western sage grouse) were candidates for listing under the Endangered Species Act of 1973.  In addition, 11 species of plants and six species of birds were cited as being listed as either threatened or endangered by Washington State. 



A review of information from the Hanford Site Occurrence reporting system and discussions with 283-W Facility personnel reveals that there have been no known onsite or offsite deaths, injuries, significant property damage or offsite environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place for the last 5 years from the 283-W Facility. 



Because the eligibility analysis concluded that the 283-W Facility is a Program 1 process, development of an accident prevention program is not required. 



The chlorine system operations and maintenance are performed using pre-approved procedures.  Chlorine leak detectors install

ed at the chlorine containers and at two other locations in the facility provide immediate alarm notification to the facility operator and automatically initiates a '911' call to hazardous material emergency response personnel in the event a chlorine leak is experienced.  Facility emergency operating procedures provide immediate emergency response and personnel protection actions for facility personnel.  Sitewide emergency response procedures provide for notification to local, and community emergency response agencies and organizations.  The facility chlorine leak detector and alarm notification systems are tested weekly to ensure reliability. 



The Building Emergency Plan for the 283-W (HNF-IP-0263-283W) was developed in accordance with RM Program guidelines (EPA 550 B 98-010).  This plan includes procedures for, or references to, procedures for informing the public and emergency response agencies if an accidental release should occur.  Procedures also include requirements for documentation of proper first aid and emergency medical treatment necessary to treat human exposure, and procedures and measures necessary for emergency response after an accidental release. 



Additionally, training drills are scheduled quarterly at the facility and a chlorine release drill is conducted annually in an attempt to continually improve safety.

A separate scenario is for the operation of the Tank Waste Treatment and Immobilization Plant (WTP) is located on the Hanford Site, a 580-square-mile (1 ,450-square-kilometer) US Department of Energy (DOE) site in southeastern Washington State. The WTP is located in the East portion of the 200 Area, just outside the

easternmost fence line of the 200 East Area, near the center of the Hanford Site. WTP is the cornerstone of DOE's mission to treat a portion of approximately 56 million gallons of chemical and radioactive waste contained in aging underground storage tanks located on the Hanford Site in Washington. The nuclear waste is the result of more than four decades of reactor operations and plutonium production for national defense. The aging storage infrastructure poses a threat to the

environment. The solution to this problem is to safely and cost-effectively retrieve, process, and immobilize this waste so that it no longer poses an environmental concern. The DOE Office of River Protection (ORP) in Richland, Washington is responsible for the overall contract management and

direction of the activities necessary to remediate the Hanford tank waste.

The WTP Project involves designing, building, and commissioning a plant to immobilize a portion of an estimated 56 million gallons of chemical and radioactive waste stored in 177 aging underground tanks at DOE's Hanford Site near Richland, Washington. The waste was accumulated between 1944 and 1989, when the Hanford Site processed plutonium and other materials for nuclear defense. The WTP will vitrify the tank waste into a chemic

ally immobile glass that is environmentally stable. The WTP treatment processes are designed to immobilize the waste constituents in a glass matrix by vitrification and to treat the offgas from the processes to a level that protects human health and the environment. To date there have been zero offsite chemical releases from the WTP.

Anhydrous ammonia (NH3) is stored at WTP as a liquefied gas. Ammonia is transferred as a gas from the ammonia storage vessels for use within the facility. Offgas from the waste treatment process passes through a catalytic oxidizer/reducer skid housing a heat recovery unit, an electric heater, VOC catalyst, and SCR catalyst to remove volatile organic compounds, carbon monoxide, nitrogen oxide compounds in the offgas stream. The heat recovery exchange first raises the offgas temperature using the hot offgas from the catalyst beds. The electric heater is used to supplement the heat recovery exchange primarily during start-up and when operating with low NOx concentrations. The heated offgas is passed through the VOC catalyst to oxidize VOCs and carbon monoxide to carbon dioxide and water vapor. The offgas is then injected with a mixture of ammonia vapor and air from an ammonia/air dilution skid. Following ammonia injection, the offgas is passed through the SCR catalyst to reduce NOx to nitrogen and water vapor. The reduction reaction is exothermic, significantly increasing the offgas temperature. The outgoing hot offgas is cooled down in the heat exchanger and concurrently serves as the heating media for the incoming offgas. The cooled offgas stream is then directed to the Caustic Scrubber for acid gas removal and final cooling.

The Project implements and maintains procedures to respond promptly, efficiently, and effectively to emergencies involving WTP activities or operations at the construction site. The applicable requirements of federal, state, and local agencies are integrated into a single comprehensive Hanford Site emergency manag

ement program (EMP). There are five elements of the Hanford Site EMP.

These elements are:

? Emergency planning which includes identification of hazards and threats, hazard mitigation, development and preparation of emergency plans and procedures, and

? identification of personnel and resources needed for an effective response;

? emergency preparedness which includes acquisition and maintenance of resources, training, drills, and exercises;

? emergency response which includes the application of resources to mitigate consequences to workers, the public, the environment, and the national security, and the initiation of recovery from an emergency;

? recovery which includes planning for and taking actions following termination of the emergency to return the facility/operations to normal; and

? readiness assurance which includes assessments and documentation to ensure that stated emergency capabilities are sufficient to implement emergency plans.

The EMP ensures that a coordinated emergency response organization can respond to and mitigate emergencies. The EMP complies with the emergency planning requirements established by WAC 173-303-350, Contingency Plan and Emergency Procedures, for implementation during an unplanned spill, release, fire, explosion, or natural phenomenon.

The discoverer of an event (e.g., fire, chemical release) initiates response to the event that includes immediate activities to mitigate the event if possible. In such cases, actions may include shutting down systems, isolating materials, or performing other facility specific response actions when

appropriate. Facility procedures also direct protective actions for personnel. In other events, resources outside the facility may be required. In these cases, the general response approach emergency telephone number. Upon being contacted, the emergency center assesses the situation and notifies the

primary response agencies - the Hanford Fire Department and Hanford Patrol - that respond and ensu

re implementation of the Hanford Incident Command System (ICS).

The Hanford ICS is an integrated emergency management system with clearly defined responsibilities and communication pathways consistent with the National Incident Management System (NIMS) that provides a graded approach for emergency management based upon the needs of the event. Additionally, the Hanford ICS is designed to support predesignated and trained facility emergency response organization (ERO) members (i.e., Building Emergency Director, Building Warden, etc.) to

complete required emergency response activities and to support emergency response agencies in the implementation of incident mitigation strategies. The senior Hanford Fire Department official becomes the Incident Commander (IC), unless the event is determined to primarily be a security event, in which case the Hanford Fire Department and Hanford Patrol will operate under a unified command system with Hanford Patrol making all decisions pertaining to security. When the Hanford ICS is established, a coordinated effort to plan and implement additional mitigative activities commences. In addition, the consequences of the event are further analyzed, and additional protective actions are implemented through the use of Hanford Site Emergency Alerting System components and barricades if determined necessary.

Whenever there is an event at Hanford, certain notifications are required depending upon the type and severity of the event. These notifications would include management notifications, activation of emergency response personnel, and offsite agency notifications as necessary. These notifications are performed primarily by the Hanford Emergency Operations Center (EOC). For events that do not meet emergency criteria but could cause public concern or media interest, local and state emergency management agencies are notified as well as state regulatory agencies for information purposes. If the event exceeds regulatory criteria, the appropria

te regulatory agencies are notified immediately.

Concurrent with the immediate notifications to the appropriate regulatory agencies, if the event is severe enough to be classified as an Alert, Site Area Emergency, or General Emergency, state and county agencies are notified within 15 minutes of declaration of the emergency. This notification allows the agencies to implement protective actions for their populations if necessary, and to begin mobilization of resources. In addition, preplanned protective actions are implemented for site

personnel and the Hanford EOC is activated to support the Incident Command Organization and coordinate interface with offsite agencies.

Upon mitigation of the event to the point the situation is stabilized and ensuring that actions have been taken to prevent reoccurrence, the event is terminated, and the recovery effort begins. Recovery is the process of planning for and implementing actions to return the facility/process to pre-event

conditions. Actions could include activities such as equipment repair, decontamination, proper storage of waste generated, and providing any follow-up reporting to appropriate regulatory agencies.
